When I was younger we used to live across from a park. There used to be this kid who lived in a government house, the most foul person you would ever meet.
One day he decides to go to the park with this sling shot trying to shoot anything that moves. He focuses on a tree full of crows, but lucky his shitty homemade slingshot had no power and couldn't hit anything.
Everytime I see him I tell him to fuck off or I'll call that cops. He never listens and the cops do jack shit, anyways I look out my window one day and there he is walking to the park with this sling shot.
I get the phone ready to call the cops again, and watch him. I yell I'm calling the cops, he ignores it and loads his slingshot. Out of nowhere rocks and other objects fall from the tree, pelting this little shit and drawing blood.
He cries in pain, and is covering his eye with blood streaming from his face. It turns out the crows had armed themselves with rocks and ball bearings from the local mechanic shop, and gave this guy some bird justice.
Didn't see the little shit after that, guess they moved to a new government house.
Crows are smart birds, but murderous in a flock.

WRITING.TITLE: How do tow truck operators bypass the law?
WRITING.TEXT:
I watched a small segment about tow truck rackets operating in city suburbs.
How it works is, the victim parks there car in an area monitored by the tow truck operator. They haul your car off to there private impound lot, and charge you $100's of dollars to release the car.
More information can be found here http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/brisbane-tow-truck-ripoff-trapping-motorists-raking-in-thousands/news-story/fafbc5bd35590ab89f1a34d05c2e6856
The scam seems illegal, but there must be some legal ground that these operaters stand on. It just seems as if these guys operate above the law somehow.
My question is how do business that operate in such a shoddy manner and get away with it was from a legal prescriptive?

WRITING.TEXT:
My friend uses to work as a health care assistant in a nursing home. There was an elderly lady there, who kids would visit her for less then a 5 minutes, do paper work, pay fees and leave.
My friend would sit down and talk to this person every shift, she lived such an amazing life which was full of stories.
Her family would never send see her holidays or birthdays, yet my friend would always get her something.
When she dead she donated millions of dollars of her assets to cancer research, as her husband died from it.
But she left my friend quite a nice cash inheritance, and jewellery.
Her family got jack shit haha

On the negative side:
-the law market is not improving and finding a job is becoming harder
-competition for graduate level jobs have increased significantly
-grades, work history, extra curricular activities, and networking connections fuel most hiring decision
Overall I say you should do what makes you happy, only you can shape the future you want, even if it takes a bit more hard work.

The great part about conciliation is that it is more flexible and a better communication platform for two disputing parties. The main issue you may face is who has the better leverage to exercise more power throughout the process.
As suggested above you should try to contact a lawyer who can at least advise you of the main points of concerns, risks, and how to minimise these.
Many people on here can't give you specific advice as no one knows the facts of the case.
Best thing you can do is understand the situation, take out all emotional bias, prove your case based on facts, and know your employee rights.
Most of this information can be gathered from your employee contract, government websites based in your state, and free legal aid.

WRITING.TITLE: Lawyer awakes from surgery
WRITING.TEXT:
And can't see see anything, he yells out for the nurse.
He hears the nurse come running in, and asks "What's wrong?"
The lawyer replies, " I came in for a knee operation and now I am blind! I am going to sue you, the hospital, the doctor, the..."
Before he can finish the nurse removes the bandage covering the lawyers eyes.
The lawyer yells, "Why the hell did you cover my eye!"
The nurse answered, "There's a fire across the street, and we didn't want you to think you had died."

WRITING.TITLE: Gangster vists a lawyer
WRITING.TEXT:
A gangster sets up a meeting with a lawyer.
The gangster asks the lawyer, "How can I get away with murder?"
The lawyer replies, "I don't know".
The gangster asks the lawyer, "How can I get away with armed robbery?"
The lawyer replies, "I don't know".
The gangster asks the lawyer, "How can I get away with drug trafficking?"
The lawyer replies, "I don't know".
The annoyed gangster says to the lawyer, " Well what the hell do you know? "
The lawyer looks down at his watch and smiles, and then says" That your bill will be $2,000".

WRITING.TITLE: Cost to start a suburban law firm
WRITING.TEXT: I am curious to find out how much were your law firm start up cost?

I think you are better off having a consultation with a lawyer.
Many things to be considered such as the payment liabilities, your personal circumstances, the regulatory aspects, and overall the legality behind actually buying and transferring the debt.
If I was you speak to your accountant, who may be able to refer you to a suitable lawyer who specialises in such areas.

I don't see a real issue why you can't undertake the bachelor of law option. A JD does cost more per year than a LLB, but in QLD they are both seen equally as I have heard. But most people opt for a LLB as the course material is slightly easier (apparently) and the cost are significantly lower.
Overall it is more a personal thing in Australia, whereas in the USA a JD is more pronounced than a standard LLB.
I believe there was an article on lawyers weekly recently summing up the real differences.
http://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/news/19739-law-dean-slams-juris-doctors-as-problematic
